title: Major
description: The Army's Military Intelligence (MI) is responsible for all intelligence gathered or learned during Army missions. MI Officers are always out front, providing essential intelligence and in many cases saving Soldiers who are fighting on the front lines. Military Intelligence Officers also assess risks associated with friendly and enemy courses of action and act to counter or neutralize identified intelligence threats. The MI Officer also uses intelligence systems and data to reduce uncertainty of enemy, terrain and weather conditions for a commander. Military Intelligence Officer provides the commander with all-source intelligence assessments and estimates at the tactical, operational, and strategic levels dealing with enemy capabilities, intentions, vulnerabilities, effects of terrain and weather on operations, and predicts enemy courses of action. Directs tasking of intelligence collection assets; produces threat estimates to support doctrine, training; and combat developments; ensures proper dissemination of intelligence information and products; manages interrogation operations of enemy prisoners of war and line crossers; interprets imagery from overhead and other systems; directs counterintelligence and operational security operations; performs clandestine human intelligence operations and manages signals intelligence operations including jamming and participating in performing deception operations. Manages these tasks at all echelons.

title: Director
description: Mr. Rick Holden will be starting a polygraph school in the United Kingdom and has offered for me to become the first Director. At the present time we have a total of 13 students who will begin their initial training 06 May 2014 at the College of Policing in the UK. It is an honor to start a school and I am hoping that their will be many more to follow in the coming years. The initial training will be 10 weeks with an 11th week were specific training will be received concerning Post Conviction Sex Offender Testing (PCSOT). This will then be followed up by internships and then we will continue with our journey by providing quality control for the work that they do. I am looking forward to this next chapter in my life.

title: Command Language Program Manager
description: - Supports the largest linguist unit within the Intelligence and Security Command (INSCOM), the 704th Military Intelligence Brigade - Coordinates local, Department of the Army, and Department of Defense language schools for approximately 350 unit linguists - Trained 11 subordinate language program managers within the brigade and trained 3 language managers from another Ft Meade unit - Supervises 11 subordinate language managers, establishing and developing standard processes for position tasks - Coordinates with higher headquarters for training resources, establishing and maintaining a language library for use by unit linguists as well as linguists from other Ft Meade units - Develops fiscal year projected language training and travel for all unit linguists, as well as subordinate language managers - Coordinates and maintains budget records for both reporting purposes as well as tracking budgetary spending - Reviewing authority for itineraries and funds for all unit linguists in the military travel computer program - Maintains and tracks a budget of thousands of dollars for language training and materials to be utilized by approximately 350 military linguists - Liaisons with higher command in regards to the establishment of procedures and budget issues - Monitors and tracks unit linguists language proficiency, coordinating FLPP orders with finance personnel - Tracks and schedules testing and training opportunities and documentation for unit linguists - Coordinates and develops all documentation for a Joint service language competition, an event that consisted of all five (5) military services located on Ft Meade, MD and six (6) languages - Subject Matter Expert and the point of contact for language programs and tasks for other Command Language Program Managers within the Intelligence and Security Command (INSCOM) and other Major Commands/units
headquarters:

Suite B
Fredericksburg,
VA
22407
United States

name: Betty Asbury

title: All Source Analyst/Watch Officer
description: - Supported US Army, Europe (USAREUR) G2 (Intelligence) Watch Desk and the 66th Military Intelligence Brigade Counterintelligence/Human Intelligence cell - Utilized classified search tools to vett unclear personnel within both the European and Middle East Theaters, in support of military operations, in order to determine access eligibility and writing analytical reports for those with founded derogatory reporting - Prepared a range of analytical and technical reports and briefing slides in response to taskings from US Army, Europe Intelligence Office (G2), as well as other offices, focusing on force-protection and intelligence situations that would affect US Army, Europe personnel - Acted as the focal point receiving, processing and responding to all intelligence-related matters in the USAREUR Operations Center (COIC) and monitor the status of all current and pending intelligence related actions - Was the Subject Matter Expert for all intelligence related subjects, working with analysts from other intelligence fields and offices - Responded, following Standard Operating Procedures, to emergencies that involved USAREUR personnel, both in Europe (Eastern and Western), the United States, and in the Middle East - Provided complex analysis, as well as intelligence support, for incoming time-sensitive issues.
name: Betty Asbury

title: Reports Analyst
description: - Supported a MACOM unit in processing atmospheric reports from nine districts in the Southern Region of Iraq - Prepared open and all source reporting, determining the significance and reliability of unclassified documentation before distributing to various government agencies, military units and personnel - Wrote and compiled any Requests for Information (RFI) pertaining to atmospheric and intelligence information for both US and NATO military personnel - Ensured correct classification on documentation in order to avoid compromises of classified or sensitive information - Wrote analytical reports for G2 (Intelligence) briefings, representing the Iraqi Advisor Task Force (IQATF) program during high-level briefings - Edit and format unclassified documents, ensuring that it is legible and in proper grammatical structure from 12 Multi-Functional Teams, comprised of SOF personnel and local nationals, throughout Southern Iraq - Validated information from received reports from the Multi-Functional Teams as well as the Iraqi Special Advisors to ensure received information is supported by other classified and unclassified sources - Inputted edited documents into a database to ensure the information is updated for reference checks by outside agencies and military units.
name: Betty Asbury

title: Local National Interpreter Hiring Assistant
description: - Supported NATO and US military forces within Southern Iraq by providing competent interpreters - Tested local nationals on their knowledge of the English language (tested in Speaking, Listening, Reading, and Language Comprehension), ensuring qualified linguists for US and Coalition troops throughout Southern Iraq - Maintained and developed administrative, testing, and training files for over 3,000 Active and Inactive local national linguists who were located throughout Iraq - Interacted with Site Managers and Assistants, as well as other Local National Linguist Program Managers and Assistants, to coordinate hiring of local national linguists - Developed a language program Standard Operating Procedure for the Local National Linguist Program to ensure program uniformity of hiring and testing requirements for the sites throughout Iraq - Established a new linguist testing and hiring site as well as training the newly hired Program Assistant - Coordinated movement for Local National Linguists from the Southern Region of Iraq to the West and Central Regions - Coordinated with military units and civilian security organizations to ensure proper security screening of Local National Linguists - Developed and maintained databases to track and handle the movement and testing information of Local National Linguists - Ad hoc administrative duties that relate to the CAT I Program in the Southern Region
name: Betty Asbury

title: Major / Brigade S-3 (Director of Operations)
description: Served as a Brigade S-3 (Director of Operations) for Task Force Observe, Detect, Identify and Neutralize Enhanced (TF ODIN-E), an Aerial Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance (A-ISR) Brigade (a unit from the Intelligence and Security Command-INSCOM) in Afghanistan consisting of over 1000 personnel (military and Civilian) and over 75 aircraft (50 manned and 15 unmanned) and associated ground support equipment valued in excess of $790,000,000, which received, assessed and distributed intelligence related to tactical and strategic threats in combat. Hand-picked from a pool of 200 other Military Intelligence Aviation Majors for this position. Directly contributed to the targeting of enemy high-value individuals (HVI) for both counterterrorism/counterinsurgency and law enforcement/security forces. Performed duties as an air reconnaissance Pilot in the RC-12X Guardrail airplane conducting signals intelligence (SIGINT) collection and antiterrorism/force protection (AT/FP) operations in combat. Coordinated, manned and supervised the brand-new Brigade Headquarters (HQ) standing-up as it started to receive initial personnel and automation equipment. Integrated new A-ISR assets into the brigade as they departed Operation New Dawn in Iraq and arrived at Operation Enduring Freedom (OEF) in Afghanistan. Served as an Accident Investigator conducting a sensitive international Aviation accident investigation in Afghanistan. This assignment was cut short due to the President's order to reduce force numbers in Afghanistan, therefore all members of my Headquarters staff were rotated home early, including myself. Awarded the Afghanistan Campaign Medal (ACM) with two Campaign Stars (CS) and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) Medal for the International Security Assistance Force (ISAF).

description: Aviation Planner supervising one Noncommissioned officer and fifteen professional civilian scenario writers and support staff orchestrating major, multinational military training exercises. Successfully transitioned the scenario plans into worthwhile training exercises by acting as tea m leader for the many different staff sections from diverse disciplines and backgrounds. Served in Germany, the United States, and on three official visits to the Kosovo Force (KFOR) in Kosovo. Planned, coordinated and facilitated all Aviation and Unmanned Aircraft Systems (UAS) use of the Hohenfels Training Area (HTA) and restricted military airspace above. Served as the primary planner for three brigade-level KFOR Mission Readiness Exercises (MRE) at the HTA, planning, coordinating and training peacekeeping, law enforcement and intelligence operations. Also served as UH-1H Iroquois helicopter Pilot, Aviation Observer/Controller (O/C) and as a UAS O/C during training exercises. Performed duties as a Battle Captain in the Division Tactical Operations Center (DTOC), orchestrating all movements, training, safety and security measures during the exercises. Escorted and briefed high-ranking US and foreign officers visiting the training area. Conducted direct negotiations with the Slovenian Ministry of Defense allowing a 1200 Soldier Battle Group to utilize the HTA for their pre-deployment MRE.

description: Air Reconnaissance Company Commander and RC-12K Guardrail Common Sensor (GRCS) airplane Pilot conducting signals intelligence (SIGINT) collection and antiterrorism/force protection (AT/FP)operations (the company was part of the 66th Military Intelligence Brigade, also part of the Intelligence and Security Command-INSCOM). Served in the United States, Germany, Romania and during Operation Iraqi Freedom (OIF) in combat. Commanded an RQ-5A/MQ-5B Hunter Unmanned Aircraft Systems (UAS) unit comprised of 70 personnel (Soldiers and Civilians). Maintained and employed eight aircraft and 45 ground vehicles worth over $27,000,000 dollars. The unit flew over 900 hours on Imagery Intelligence (IMINT) missions in combat. Personally flew Signals Intelligence (SIGINT) missions in the RC-12K GRCS in combat. Directly contributed to the targeting of enemy high-value individuals (HVI) for both counterterrorism/counterinsurgency and law enforcement/security forces. Awarded the Iraqi Campaign Medal (ICM) with two Campaign Stars (CS). Successfully fielded to the unit the brand-new MQ-5B Hunter UAS as it replaced the older RQ-5B and ensured all UAS leaders, operators and maintainers were trained on the new system. Additionally served as a Military Intelligence Detachment (MID) Commander in Romania for six weeks in charge of 130 personnel (Soldiers and Civilians) and over $30,000,000 dollars’ worth of equipment conducting Aviation and Military Intelligence (MI) operations. Led the negotiating team that negotiate the permission to operate US Army UAS in Romanian airspace. Personally selected by higher headquarters at INSCOM to provide input on the development, procurement and fielding of two new US Army UAS systems (one UAV type; one SIGINT payload type).

title: Captain / Squadron S-2 (Intelligence and Security Manager)
description: Squadron S-2 (Intelligence and Security Officer), OH-58D(I) Kiowa Warrior helicopter Pilot-In-Command (PIC) and Air Mission Commander (AMC) conducting armed reconnaissance and security operations. Led one warrant officer and six enlisted Soldiers in Squadron intelligence and security operations and training. Maintained and employed the section's three tactical vehicles and ten small arms. Produced and briefed battlefield terrain analysis and the enemy intelligence situation prior to launching helicopter aircrews flying combat missions during Operation Enduring Freedom in Afghanistan. Oversaw all aspects of unit programs on Intelligence Preparation of the Battlefield, Operational Security, Information Security, Antiterrorism-Force Protection, Counterespionage and Crime Prevention. Oversaw all unit personnel security clearances and background investigations. Recognized by the Squadron Executive Officer (XO) for ensuring the unit successfully passed a major security readiness inspection by performing multiple preparatory no-notice arms rooms and barracks security inspections. Resourced, trained and led the unit’s opposing force during small-unit training exercises. Served as the Aviation Task Force (ATF) Air Liaison Officer (ALO) to an Airborne Brigade Combat Team conducting counterinsurgency operations, both in combat and in garrison. Planned scout air insertions behind enemy lines, air assault operations and combat resupply runs across the entire eastern half of Afghanistan. Supported regular and Special Forces (including foreign units) with US Aviation assets, conducting attack, reconnaissance, security, transportation and medevac support. Served as an Assistant to an Investigating Officer (IO) conducting a sensitive international Aviation accident investigation in Iraq. Awarded the Bronze Star Medal (BSM), the Global War on Terrorism Expeditionary (GWOTE) medal and the Global War on Terrorism Service (GWOTS) medal.

title: Special Forces Battalion Operations Warrant Officer
description: I am the Battalion Operations Warrant Officer and Senior Warrant Officer Advisor/Mentor for a combat ready Special Forces Battalion. I provide tactical and technical guidance to the Battalion S3 and Commander for Special Forces operations to include Special, Irregular, and Unconventional Warfare, Foreign Internal Defense, Special Reconnaissance, Direct Action and Advanced Special Operations Techniques in support of Unified, Joint, Combined or Unilateral operations. I develop plans and concepts for future contingency operations and exercises to be executed by the Battalion. I coordinate, track and support detachment and company CONUS and OCONUS training events and operations. When needed I serve as the Operational Control Element / Advanced Special Operations Manager to synchronize operations and intelligence and serve in the Battalion Targeting Cell at Forward Operating Bases during operations. I mentor and advise 23 subordinate Warrant Officers serving as Special Forces Detachment Commanders and a myriad of Staff positions. I advise the Commander on positioning these Warrant Officers to maximize his combat power while facilitating their professional military education and foster their experience thru challenging assignments.
